titles.title: Uses of Results of Regional Climate Model Experiments for Impacts and Adaptation Studies: the Example of NARCCAP

citation.author: LO Mearns
citation.unstructured_citation: Mearns LO, Bukovsky M, Pryor S, Magaña V. Downscaling of climate information. In: Ohring G, editor. Climate change in North America. New York: Springer; 2014. p. 201–50. This book chapter provides an overview of all different types of downscaling specifically over North America.

citation.author: EP Maurer
citation.unstructured_citation: Maurer EP, Brekke L, Pruitt T, Duffy P. Fine-resolution climate projections enhance regional climate change impact studies. Eos. 2007;88(47):504.

citation.author: EP Maurer
citation.unstructured_citation: Maurer EP, Brekke L, Pruitt T, Thrasher B, Long J, Duffy P, et al. An enhanced archive facilitating climate impacts analysis. Bull Am Meteorol Soc. 2014;95(7):1011–9. doi: 10.1175/BAMS-D-13-00126.1 . This article provides a very good overview of the basics of statistical downscaling of CMIP3 and CMIP5 and describes the preparation of datasets for use by the impacts and adaptation communities.

citation.author: J Chen
citation.unstructured_citation: Chen J, Brissette FP, Chaumont D, Braun M. Performance and uncertainty evaluation of empirical downscaling methods in quantifying the climate change impacts on hydrology over two North American river basins. J Hydrol. 2013;479:200–14. This article is a useful example of comparing the effect of empirical and dynamical downscaling methods on the calculation of future hydrologic impacts.

citation.author: U.S. EPA (Environmental Protection Agency)
citation.volume_title: Watershed modeling to assess the sensitivity of streamflow, nutrient, and sediment loads to potential climate change and urban development in 20 U.S. watersheds
citation.unstructured_citation: U.S. EPA (Environmental Protection Agency). Watershed modeling to assess the sensitivity of streamflow, nutrient, and sediment loads to potential climate change and urban development in 20 U.S. watersheds. Washington, DC: National Center for Environmental Assessment; 2013. This document (and Johnson et al. below) provides a very good example of the use of NARCCAP output in a large hydrologic study. It also provides some contrasts between empirically downscaled GCM results and NARCCAP and the effect these different scenarios have on hydrologic outputs, such as stream flow.

citation.journal_title: J Water Resour Plan Manag ASCE
citation.author: TE Johnson
citation.unstructured_citation: Johnson TE, Butcher JB, Parker A, Weaver CP. Investigating the sensitivity of U.S. streamflow and water quality to climate change: U.S. EPA Global Change Research Program’s 20 Watersheds Project. J Water Resour Plan Manag ASCE. 2012;138(5):453–64. This document provides a very good example of the use of NARCCAP output in a large hydrologic study. It also provides some contrasts between empirically downscaled GCM results and NARCCAP and the effect these different scenarios have on hydrologic outputs, such as stream flow.
